perturbation.original_text: The Trust shall not be liable for any error of judgment or mistake of law or for any act or omission in the oversight, administration or management of the Trust or the performance of its duties hereunder, except for willful misfeasance, bad faith or gross negligence in the performance of its duties, or by reason of the reckless disregard of its obligations and duties hereunder. As used in this Section 4, the term "Sponsor" shall include Domini and/or any of its affiliates and the directors, officers and employees of Domini and/or any of its affiliates.
perturbation.changed_text: As used in this Section 4, the term "Sponsor" shall include Domini and/or any of its affiliates and the directors, officers and employees of Domini and/or any of its affiliates. The Sponsor shall not be liable for any error of judgment or mistake of law or for any act or omission in the oversight, administration or management of the Trust or the performance of its duties hereunder, except for willful misfeasance, bad faith or gross negligence in the performance of its duties, or by reason of the reckless disregard of its obligations and duties hereunder.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the order of sentences in Section 4, the initial emphasis is shifted from the Sponsor's limitation of liability to a definition of who constitutes the 'Sponsor.' This could obscure the critical limitation of liability clause, affecting its prominence and potentially impacting its enforceability.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 17(h) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 restricts exculpatory clauses that relieve investment company personnel from liability for conduct falling below certain standards. By obscuring the liability limitation within a definitional statement, it may be argued that the clause is less clear and conspicuous, potentially running afoul of the spirit, if not the letter, of §17(h) which aims to ensure that fund managers and sponsors are held accountable for misconduct and that investors are not misled by overly broad liability waivers.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, without the payment of any penalty, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 60 days' written notice to the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 60 days' written notice to the other party. The payment of any penalty is not required.
perturbation.explanation: By separating the phrase 'without the payment of any penalty' from the main clause regarding termination, the reader's understanding of the termination terms may be affected. This separation introduces ambiguity as it may lead to disputes over whether penalties are indeed waived upon termination. The original text links the lack of penalty to termination, now it's a separated statement.
perturbation.law_explanation: M.G.L. c. 93A, § 2 prohibits unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce. By creating a clause where it isn't clear that there is no penalty on termination, it opens the door to deceptive practices. The wording could confuse a reasonable consumer into thinking that penalties may exist. This could be deemed a violation of consumer protection laws requiring clear and unambiguous contract terms.

perturbation.original_text: Any notices under this Agreement shall be in writing addressed and delivered personally, by telecopy or mailed postage-paid to the other party at such address as such other party may designate in accordance with this Section 9 for the receipt of such notice. Until further notice to the other party, it is agreed that the address of the Trust shall be 536 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, New York 10012, and the address of Domini shall be 536 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, New York 10012.
perturbation.changed_text: Any notices under this Agreement shall be in writing addressed and delivered personally, or mailed postage-paid to the other party at such address as such other party may designate in accordance with this Section 9 for the receipt of such notice. Until further notice to the other party, it is agreed that the address of the Trust shall be 536 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, New York 10012, and the address of Domini shall be 536 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, New York 10012.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'by telecopy' from the means of delivering notices, it removes a valid option which might be critical when documents are needed to be sent during a time-sensitive period.
perturbation.law_explanation: UETA Section 8 deals with the attribution of electronic records and electronic signatures. By removing telecopy as an acceptable method of communication, this may contradict provisions allowing for electronic transmission of documents, especially if telecopy is commonly used in the relevant industry and considered an electronic record. Denying telecopy could unfairly disadvantage a party reliant on electronic communication, contradicting the principles behind UETA of placing electronic transactions on the same footing as paper-based transactions.
